content: I built this thing almost entirely out of household items and trash like 95 98
percent of it is just crap that you probably have lying around not all of it
there's a few tiny bits I use that we're not household items but you don't have
to use those you could you can build this out of trash hey guys welcome back
to black magic crafts I've been wanting to do another modern or post-apocalyptic
build for a while now so I decided to go with what is a really classic bit of
wargaming terrain and that's building something out of cans it's almost a rite
of passage as a terrain builder to make some scatter terrain out of aluminum
cans and I'm really surprised that I haven't done it yet so I finally did and
I decided to build this fuel tank or oil tank whatever you want to call it it's a
really accessible project like I said it's made almost entirely out of
household items I used a few 3d printed bits just as little extra embellishments
but it absolutely does not need them and you can absolutely rock out a project
like this with with random junk this one didn't turn out amazing it was a bit of
a struggle but this project was really more of an experimentation than anything
else and I learned a fair bit while building it that's gonna help me out on
future projects essentially I just kept throwing things at it until I felt it
was built and kept throwing paint on it until I felt it was sufficiently painted
this sort of thing is great for a lot of games like kill team Nick Rimando
gasps lands whatever your zombie killing game of choice is essentially anything
that takes place in a modern or futuristic world or alternative universe
anything that might have oil tanks it's it's gonna work and it's pretty fun
already let's just build the damn thing let's talk about cans just for a second
people doing these builds often default to typical 355 milliliter
pop or beer cans I think that's a bit of a mistake they're just too recognizable
instead I chose this longer and more slender can it will be slightly less
noticeable in the finished piece as a recognizable object and I think its
length actually better suits a fuel container so if you're planning on
building some stuff like this keep an eye out for interestingly sized and
shaped containers first thing that needs to be done to any can is to make one end
solid you got to cover up that drinkie hole I figured I'd fill it in with a
circle cut from chipboard but I realized immediately it would be really difficult
to cut the perfect circle with a knife months ago a company had sent me a bunch
of foam cutting tools to play with including a circle cutter I never really
got around to using them they didn't quite suit me from what I saw but I
figured I'd give this circle cutter a go here
it didn't work it created a sort of spiral cut on the chipboard and the
blade wasn't sharp enough to make it through the dense paper turns out the
resistance from the chipboard caused the blade to bend inward and kind of made it
spiral in so this option was a no-go but since I had it out and set up to the
right size I decided to cut the circle out of foam core instead this worked a
fair bit better but the cut still wasn't as clean as I would have liked through
the actual foam layer I'm just not in love with this tool the foam core itself
was far too thick for the recess in the can so using a handheld hot wire cutter
and the lip of the can as a guide I cut the foam core to the perfect thickness
the edges were a bit rough and had some small gaps that I wanted to fill since
this would end up looking like an old rusty metal thing I figured I'd turn to
the old super glue and baking soda method to fill in the gaps as this would
be really strong and also kind of look like welds the speaking of strong I'm
sure some of you are wondering about the durability of the can itself aluminum
cans are quite weak and very easy to crush and that's certainly true here I
think if you're making some of these and really want them to be durable it's
worth testing out different ways to fill them to make them more solid especially
if you're gonna like take these to a club or something you could go with
something like plaster but that would be really heavy alternatively you could
probably fill them with expanding spray foam although I haven't tested that
myself but I may do so in the future if I decide to build more of these
originally I had planned on this thing being freestanding with no base because
I really dislike big bases on terrain so I needed some sort of feet or holders
for it since they would need to be a bizarre shape that perfectly conformed
to the circumference of the can I used paper to mock up the pieces
once I had shapes that would work I used them as templates to cut the shapes out
of foam core I want to say here that this foam core I'm using isn't the easy
peel stuff from Dollar Tree its Studio brand from Dollarama
and the paper is very well secured this stuff doesn't peel off this is far
better when you want the paper to remain in place it also has black foam on the
interior which doesn't really affect anything with the paper in place but
it's worth noting the edges of the foam core were both ugly and susceptible to
easy damage I solved both problems at once by using some plastic zip ties to
create cladding for the edges they are the perfect width and have a built in
Ridge pattern that will work great on a project like this a nice way to add some
simple rivets to foam core is by using a small pin to make a bunch of little
puncture holes it's not as nice as if you take the time to get something to
make raised rivets but it's infinitely simpler to do the nice thing about
building old rusty metal terrain is that you can be really messy with the glue
and it doesn't matter much it'll just paint up like welds and heavy rust or at
least that's my excuse in order to make this piece more useful in game I wanted
to add a catwalk on top for miniatures to stand on this needed to be thin and
durable so I used my trusty medium weight chipboard to create a little
strip for some texture I thought about using granny grating but it's just a bit
heavier than I'd like so instead I used dry
mesh tape this stuff has the same pattern but it's much thinner making it
look a lot better at 28 millimeter scale this tape is awful for its actual
intended purpose of taping drywall but it's great for this it also has a
built-in adhesive which makes it easy to apply all you need to do is press it on
to the piece and cut off the excess now to dress it up a bit more and add even
more rigidity to the edges I used the same a zip ties again from before to
create a border this was pretty awkward to attach but I think it was worth the
effort not actually glue it in place I didn't trust hot glue which doesn't
stick to metal that well and super glue would just be too thin for this sort of
connection there's no way it would work I needed something goopy and thick that
had really high adhesion properties when that's the case dollar-store epoxy is
the obvious answer there's now time to add some piping I used the same bendy
straws that I used in my previous Mandalorian diorama these make great
piping in a pinch the problem is that you can't really interconnect them so
you're limited to one Bend and whatever length the straws I needed a way to make
joints now I probably could have found some coupler pieces online to 3d print
but I chose the craftier and more instantaneous approach of using what was
just lying around which happened to be larger paper straws it just worked out
that the inside diameter of the paper straws was a great fit for the plastic
bendy ones I could cut the paper straws into short segments and add joints
wherever I wanted not the most glamorous solution but there's no denying that it
worked
I really wanted some of these straws to continue down into the ground and
without a base they would just be far too fragile they'd end up bent and
broken in no time I had to resign myself to adding a base instead of making a
base that looked like ground I thought it would be better to make it look like
part of the structure this way it could still be dropped on any terrain or
battle mat and look good it also means that later I can stack it on top of
other builds if I ever make any in the same size and style I wanted to ensure
that it would not bow or get bent in the future so I put a layer of chipboard
underneath and clad the edges with more of those same zip ties well the mesh
tape has built-in adhesive I'm not sure how strong it is or whether or not it's
water soluble so before going further I decided to give it a coat of Mod Podge
just in case to make sure it was fully attached and protected from hydration
during the upcoming painting process one of my pipes was a little short and
already locked in place with glue so I cut a small strip of paper to create
another coupler layer to hide the gap I didn't do a very good job I ended up
making the strip too short and just creating another different gap the sort
of stuff tends to happen when you start rushing a build I figured I'd break out
the cotton swabs to fix this if you buy off-brand one's not q-tips but the cheap
ones from like the dollar store you can get ones that have plastic stems they're
basically a really easy source of small plastic rods that you can use in place
of the styrene ones that you get at a hobby store I could use one of these to
both hide the gap and add another layer of detail only problem is that I wanted
it to look like the pipe or bar or whatever it's supposed to be was
returning back into the larger one and not just ending in an open cut the nice
thing is that you can bend these into shape using a heat gun or like a candle
tricky with them being so short because you got to keep your hands close by and
the heat but it can be done this leads me to the most difficult and frustrating
part of the project the ladder you really needed a ladder the smart thing
to do would be to 3d print one or find one from a supplier but I needed it now
and I know most of you would rather see me struggle building something
bad-looking than print something good-looking
so I set to work trying to do it out of the cotton swab stems this was a bit of
a catastrophe and would have been so much easier if I at least had longer
ones to work with instead I had to awkwardly assemble it out of multiple
little pieces but I eventually got something that looked okay
after that exercise and frustration I said screw it let's do something easy so
I grabbed some of the leftover 3d printed bits from my Mandalorian diorama
and added some small embellishments of course this is totally optional you
could just leave these sort of things out or you could scavenge for bits to
use to add these little extra details consider taking apart old electronics or
toys for little Griebel pieces they are full of great options with all the messy
glue texture on the pieces I thought the can itself might end up looking too
smooth so I decided to try adding some heavy rust texture using super glue and
baking soda this worked ok but later I would end up deciding it was too minimal
and cover it up with something else well finally it was time to prime this
thing and move on to paint damn it
just one medium double-double please
thanks holiest of holies
listen I got to be real with you here
the paint process you are about to witness involves many unnecessary and
wasted steps and a lot of pissing around I was super indecisive about how I
wanted to do this I wanted to figure out a hell a simple rush paint job that
required little effort you know so I could bang a bunch of these out in the
future what I ended up with was a day of painting and testing to get a result
that I probably could have gotten with 10% of the steps so I'm not gonna walk
you through them all here but I am gonna show them to you just sit back and watch
the madness unfold and keep in mind the most important lesson here it's just
paint don't give yourself decision paralysis when it comes to painting just
paint the damn thing if you don't like it
paint it some more still don't like it hit it again with more paint just keep
throwing paint texture paste washes and inks at your piece until you like the
way it looks

with the paint finally at a point that I
thought was okay I moved on to some fun finishing details I wanted it to look
like some of the pipes were leaking oil so I mixed up some more five-minute
epoxy and black ink to create a fast setting oily sludge this actually looked
pretty good but I was careful not to overdo it I then remembered that I had
previously printed out some industrial warning signs from my dumpster build and
a few of them would probably look good here
now I should have added these earlier in the process so that they could have been
weathered along with everything else obviously it makes no sense for them to
be super clean in comparison to such a worn-out piece of equipment but I wanted
to use them so I did I just went back in and heavily weathered them with inks to
the point where they were almost invisible they were covered in so much
sludge but I think that was the appropriate look for this piece now I
don't think this build looks spectacular it was made from household junk and you
can kind of tell the paint job is pretty hack but you know what it really doesn't
matter it's a classic build an aluminum can
based terrain they always look a little bit off and that's part of their charm
it will work well enough in game but most importantly it let me mess around
with materials and techniques for a day and since I've usually build in the
fantasy style I'm still not really that great at these kinds of projects so
completing one just makes me a little bit better even if it's not amazing
looking but really it does look kind of cool I think what do you think
well I hope you guys in joyed this build and of this video if you did
hit the like button and let me know in the comment section below if you want to
pick up any tools or supplies to build your own
although realistically most of the stuff you just got to raid your recycling bin
and your bathroom drawer but if you need any of the other kind of tools and
supplies like knives and glue and all that you can check out my essential
equipment page on Blackmagic craft dot CA there I've listed the things that I
use the most explained why I use them and link to them so you can buy the
right thing if you really enjoy these videos I make if you get a lot of actual
tangible value out of them consider supporting the channel on patreon that
support goes a long way to ensuring that I can dedicate the time and effort and
resources into making these videos each and every week for you guys and the
community and I'd love to have you as the newest member of the black magic
crafts fellowship that's it for this week guys I'll see you again next week
